review.title: Multidefender Security Games
review.abstract: Stackelberg security game models and associated computational tools have seen deployment in a number of high-consequence security settings, such as LAX canine patrols and Federal Air Marshal Service. These models focus on isolated systems with only one defender, despite being part of a more complex system with multiple players. Furthermore, many real systems such as transportation networks and the power grid exhibit interdependencies between targets and, consequently, between decision makers jointly charged with protecting them. To understand such multidefender strategic interactions present in security, we investigate game theoretic models of security games with multiple defenders. Unlike most prior analysis, we focus on the situations in which each defender must protect multiple targets, so that even a single defender's best response decision is, in general, highly non-trivial. We start with an analytical investigation of multidefender security games with independent targets, offering an equilibrium and price-of-anarchy analysis of three models with increasing generality. In all models, we find that defenders have the incentive to over-protect targets, at times significantly. Additionally, in the simpler models, we find that the price of anarchy is unbounded, linearly increasing both in the number of defenders and the number of targets per defender. Considering interdependencies among targets, we develop a novel mixed-integer linear programming formulation to compute a defender's best response, and make use of this formulation in approximating Nash equilibria of the game. We apply this approach towards computational strategic analysis of several models of networks representing interdependencies, including real-world power networks. Our analysis shows how network structure and the probability of failure spread determine the propensity of defenders to over- or under-invest in security.

sections.text: A crucial step in calculating (or approaching) a Nash balance in a game is to consider the problem of calculating the best answer for any player (in our case defender, since the attacker's best answer is simple). sections.heading: 5.2 Approximating ASE
sections.text: Previously, Vorobeychik and Wellman (2008) presented a convergent equilibrium approximation algorithm based on simulated annealing (SA) that would be applicable in our environment; they also demonstrated in the simulation that SA is actually surpassed by a simple heuristics based on iterated best response (IBR) dynamics; here, we interpret IBR as a local search heuristically, with the property that if the starting point is a Nash equilibrium, IBR will never deviate from it (i.e., Nash equilibrium is a fixed point); clearly, then the choice of a starting point can be significant for IBR's performance, which makes it natural to consider coupling it with random restarts; our most important contribution in this section is the proof that IBR with random restarts is a highly effective equilibrium approximation approach that outperforms our environment (and outperforms several alternatives).

sections.heading: 5.3 Analysis of Multi-Defender Games on Synthetic Networks
sections.text: For our first set of experiments, we will use RIBR on 3 artificially created networks, with 40 samples for each parameter variation. First, we will illustrate and compare the results of our interdependent multi-defender game on artificial networks. We will use 3 commonly analyzed network structures: a network, erdo-re-nyi networks, and preferred connectivity networks. In all generated networks, there are 64 nodes or targets. For the latter two, we will use the Metis graphics partitioning software to divide the nodes (targets) among defenders. These software partition nodes to minimize connectivity between targets belonging to different defenders, a property that we expect them to hold together in real networks, due to efficiency considerations. We will start by considering average strategies as well as social welfare for the three different synthetic networks (network, erdo-re-probability, re-function probability, and cascade number).

sections.heading: 5.4 Results on power grid networks
sections.text: The network described above is probably the most "artificial," in which both erdo-re-nyi and preferred investment models have been developed to resemble real networks (especially the latter, which aim to replicate the scale-free characteristics of the observed networks). What is surprising, however, is that the approximate equilibrium results applied to three snippets of the actual power networks are most similar to the phenomena seen in Figure 8. In particular, over-investment in security seems to dominate, even with relatively high interdependencies, but only when decentralization is significant, while most levels of decentralization are near optimal (these are in Figure 8).

sections.heading: 5.5 Security and Network Centrality
sections.text: Finally, we consider the relationship between the centrality of the network and the strategic choice of a node. The results shown in Figure 10 show the centrality of the proximity of each node and the corresponding security in 10 cases for each network. If the interdependence of the networks is low, the security investments seem to correlate quite strongly with the proximity in synthetic networks: in other words, more central nodes invest more in security. A similar relationship can be seen in the nodes. However, this correlation largely disappears with greater interdependence, probably because the difference between a node and two nodes is distant from an attacked node (i.e. being a low-connected neighbor of a highly-connected node), in such a case, is considerably less.In the case of power networks, the correlation between centrality and strategy remains even at higher cascade probabilities. This relationship can be considered by comparing the strategy profile in the second column of Figure 9 and the proximity of p = 0.7 for the electricity network.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have expanded the current state of Stackelberg security games to include multiple defenders in non-cooperative scenarios with independent and interdependent objectives. In the independent case, we have provided complete characterizations of Nash and approximate balances, socially optimal solutions, and the price of anarchy (PoA) for three models of different generalities. Our analysis showed that defenders generally protect the targets, but different modeling assumptions lead to qualitatively different results: a simpler model leads to an unlimited PoA, whereas a more general model PoA converges to a constant as the number of defenders increases. In the interdependent case, we have developed a novel calculation framework to overcome the difficulties of a precise formal analysis of such a complex model. Our simulations describe a wide range of strategic constraints, varying cascade probability, network structure, and system decentralization. In contrast to the independent models, our results are dependent on the strength of our networks, and the behavior of our security investments.

In all models, we find that the defenders have the incentive to over-protect the targets, at times significantly.
